content.expert_insight: A written acceptance certificate provides clear, formal documentation of acceptance, which is crucial for both parties for legal, financial, and project closure purposes. It formalizes the completion of a milestone.
content.conditions: Results of services/deliverables pass acceptance tests and fulfill required acceptance criteria.
content.justification: Provides formal documentation of acceptance, which is essential for legal, financial, and project closure.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp has an obligation to provide formal acknowledgment of successful completion.
content.implication_supplier: Supplier receives formal proof of acceptance, enabling revenue recognition and invoicing.
content.text: Once the results of services/deliverables pass the acceptance tests and otherwise fulfil the required acceptance criteria, Zebracorp would typically be required to issue a written acceptance certificate evidencing the completion of acceptance tests.

content.verbatim_text: Provisional acceptance is often granted at the point in time when the deliverables substantially meet the agreed acceptance criteria.
content.plain_text: Provisional acceptance is typically granted when deliverables largely meet the agreed acceptance criteria.
content.expert_insight: This definition clarifies that 'provisional' implies a substantial, but not necessarily perfect, compliance, allowing for phased acceptance and early operational use while minor issues are addressed.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.text: Provisional acceptance is often granted at the point in time when the deliverables substantially meet the agreed acceptance criteria.

content.verbatim_text: Final acceptance will be granted subsequently once all errors and deficiencies identified during the provisional acceptance tests have been remedied and the end customer has accepted the product.
content.plain_text: Final acceptance is granted after all errors and deficiencies from provisional acceptance tests are fixed and the end customer has accepted the product.
content.expert_insight: This definition emphasizes that final acceptance requires full remediation and, crucially, alignment with end-customer acceptance, particularly in back-to-back contract scenarios.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.text: Final acceptance will be granted subsequently once all errors and deficiencies identified during the provisional acceptance tests have been remedied and the end customer has accepted the product.

content.verbatim_text: Zebracorp can agree to system element based or other partial acceptance only so long as this is in line with the corresponding acceptance provisions of our customer contract.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp can only agree to partial or system-element-based acceptance if it aligns with the customer contract's acceptance provisions.
content.expert_insight: Another critical 'back-to-back' alignment rule. Accepting partial deliverables from a subcontractor without a corresponding partial acceptance mechanism in the customer contract can create significant financial and project risks for Zebracorp.
content.conditions: Partial or system element based acceptance is in line with customer contract acceptance provisions.
content.justification: To avoid misalignment between subcontractor and customer contracts, preventing financial or project risk for Zebracorp.
content.implication_company: Protects Zebracorp from accepting and potentially paying for partial deliverables before its own customer accepts them.
content.implication_supplier: Supplier's ability to get partial acceptance is contingent on Zebracorp's customer contract terms.
content.text: Zebracorp can agree to system element based or other partial acceptance only so long as this is in line with the corresponding acceptance provisions of our customer contract.

content.verbatim_text: Note also that in the majority of cases we may be able to agree to acceptance being deemed to take place without us issuing a formal acceptance certificate when the a certain time period for completing the acceptance tests has passed (“backstop date”), or when we or our customers takes the results of the works into commercial or production use (“deemed acceptance”).
content.plain_text: Acceptance can be 'deemed' to occur without a formal certificate if a 'backstop date' (a time limit for tests) passes, or if Zebracorp or its customers begin commercial/production use of the deliverables.
content.expert_insight: These are important concepts for managing project timelines and avoiding indefinite delays. However, they carry risks if not carefully managed, as Zebracorp might inadvertently accept non-compliant work.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.text: Note also that in the majority of cases we may be able to agree to acceptance being deemed to take place without us issuing a formal acceptance certificate when the a certain time period for completing the acceptance tests has passed (“backstop date”), or when we or our customers takes the results of the works into commercial or production use (“deemed acceptance”).

content.verbatim_text: It is however recommended to verify that such deemed acceptance or backstop dates are also agreed in our corresponding customer contract (if applicable) to make sure the acceptance provisions are back-to-back.
content.plain_text: It is recommended to ensure any 'deemed acceptance' or 'backstop dates' in subcontractor contracts are also present and aligned in the corresponding customer contract, if applicable, to maintain back-to-back acceptance provisions.
content.expert_insight: This is a critical risk mitigation strategy. If Zebracorp's subcontractor contract has a deemed acceptance, but its customer contract does not, Zebracorp could be forced to accept and pay a subcontractor before its own customer has accepted, creating a financial and contractual gap.
content.conditions: Deemed acceptance or backstop dates are agreed in subcontractor contracts and a corresponding customer contract exists.
content.justification: To ensure acceptance provisions are back-to-back and avoid Zebracorp being exposed to risks of accepting from a subcontractor before its customer accepts.
content.implication_company: Protects Zebracorp from financial exposure and contractual misalignment.
content.implication_supplier: Supplier's deemed acceptance may be tied to Zebracorp's customer contract, potentially affecting their payment timeline.
content.text: It is however recommended to verify that such deemed acceptance or backstop dates are also agreed in our corresponding customer contract (if applicable) to make sure the acceptance provisions are back-to-back.

content.verbatim_text: It is also worth checking with the respective project manager that Zebracorp has sufficient time to complete system level testing before any deemed acceptance is being triggered.
content.plain_text: Confirm with the project manager that there's enough time for system-level testing before any deemed acceptance is triggered.
content.expert_insight: This is a practical operational check to prevent premature deemed acceptance of potentially faulty systems. It emphasizes the need for internal coordination between legal and project management teams.
content.conditions: N/A
content.justification: To ensure thorough testing is completed and avoid inadvertently accepting non-compliant systems.
content.implication_company: Prevents Zebracorp from being bound by deemed acceptance before adequate testing, potentially accepting faulty systems.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should be aware that Zebracorp will ensure sufficient testing time before deemed acceptance.
content.text: It is also worth checking with the respective project manager that Zebracorp has sufficient time to complete system level testing before any deemed acceptance is being triggered.

content.verbatim_text: When agreeing on a backstop date for completing the acceptance test, we should ensure that acceptance is not triggered, if the delay in completing the acceptance tests is not caused by reasons solely attributable to ZEBRACORP.
content.plain_text: When setting a backstop date for acceptance tests, ensure acceptance isn't triggered if Zebracorp is not solely responsible for the delay.
content.expert_insight: This is a crucial protection for Zebracorp. It prevents the supplier from benefiting from their own delays by triggering deemed acceptance. The backstop date should only apply if Zebracorp is the sole cause of delay.
content.conditions: Agreeing on a backstop date for completing the acceptance test.
content.justification: To prevent acceptance from being triggered due to delays not attributable to Zebracorp.
content.implication_company: Protects Zebracorp from being forced to accept deliverables due to supplier-caused delays.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers cannot rely on Zebracorp's delays (unless solely Zebracorp's fault) to trigger deemed acceptance.
content.text: When agreeing on a backstop date for completing the acceptance test, we should ensure that acceptance is not triggered, if the delay in completing the acceptance tests is not caused by reasons solely attributable to ZEBRACORP.

content.verbatim_text: Any deficiencies, errors or deviations found in the subcontractor’s performance should automatically result in an extension of time for completing the acceptance tests.
content.plain_text: Deficiencies, errors, or deviations in subcontractor performance should automatically extend the acceptance test period.
content.expert_insight: This is a fair and logical provision. If the supplier delivers non-compliant work, Zebracorp should not be penalized by having less time to test or being forced into deemed acceptance. It incentivizes quality delivery.
content.conditions: Deficiencies, errors or deviations found in the subcontractor’s performance.
content.justification: To allow Zebracorp sufficient time to re-test after remediation and ensure compliance.
content.implication_company: Ensures Zebracorp has adequate time to verify corrected deliverables without pressure from a ticking clock.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers are incentivized to deliver compliant work, as non-compliance will extend the acceptance period and delay their payment.
content.text: Any deficiencies, errors or deviations found in the subcontractor’s performance should automatically result in an extension of time for completing the acceptance tests.

content.verbatim_text: Also it is always recommended to have the subcontractor agree to send a final formal written notice to us and agree to give us a reasonable cure period before granting deemed acceptance.
content.plain_text: It's always recommended to require subcontractors to send a final formal written notice and provide a reasonable cure period before deemed acceptance is granted.
content.expert_insight: This is a vital safeguard against inadvertent deemed acceptance. It provides Zebracorp with a final warning and an opportunity to complete tests or address any issues before acceptance is automatically triggered, protecting against oversight.
content.conditions: N/A
content.justification: To avoid granting acceptance inadvertently for something that has not been properly tested.
content.implication_company: Provides a critical last chance to prevent deemed acceptance of untested or non-compliant deliverables.
content.implication_supplier: Requires suppliers to proactively communicate and provide a grace period, which can delay their deemed acceptance if Zebracorp acts on the notice.
content.text: Also it is always recommended to have the subcontractor agree to send a final formal written notice to us and agree to give us a reasonable cure period before granting deemed acceptance.

content.verbatim_text: This will avoid us granting acceptance inadvertently for something that has not been properly tested.
content.plain_text: This practice prevents inadvertently accepting deliverables that haven't been thoroughly tested.
content.expert_insight: This clearly states the benefit of the preceding guideline, emphasizing risk mitigation.
content.justification: Explains the benefit of requiring a final written notice and cure period before deemed acceptance.
content.implication_company: Protects Zebracorp from the risks associated with accepting untested or non-compliant work.
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.text: This will avoid us granting acceptance inadvertently for something that has not been properly tested.

content.verbatim_text: Whenever Zebracorp has agreed to such evaluation period, it is important to have our respective subcontractors for that particular customer agree to similar commercial evaluation period before granting Final Acceptance.
content.plain_text: If Zebracorp agrees to a commercial evaluation period with a customer, ensure corresponding subcontractors agree to a similar period before Zebracorp grants them Final Acceptance.
content.expert_insight: This is another crucial 'back-to-back' alignment. If Zebracorp's customer has an evaluation period, Zebracorp must ensure its subcontractors also have one, otherwise Zebracorp could be forced to accept from the subcontractor while its own customer is still evaluating.
content.conditions: Zebracorp has agreed to a Product or System Performance Evaluation Period with a customer.
content.justification: To maintain back-to-back alignment with customer contracts and avoid Zebracorp accepting from a subcontractor while its own customer is still evaluating.
content.implication_company: Prevents Zebracorp from being financially or contractually exposed during a customer evaluation period.
content.implication_supplier: Subcontractor's final acceptance and payment will be contingent on the customer's evaluation period.
content.text: Whenever Zebracorp has agreed to such evaluation period, it is important to have our respective subcontractors for that particular customer agree to similar commercial evaluation period before granting Final Acceptance.

content.verbatim_text: Having clear acceptance criteria in the contract will benefit both parties.
content.plain_text: Clear acceptance criteria in a contract are mutually beneficial.
content.expert_insight: This emphasizes the shared advantage of well-defined criteria, promoting transparency and reducing potential for conflict.
content.justification: Clear criteria reduce ambiguity and disputes.
content.implication_company: Ensures Zebracorp has objective standards for evaluating deliverables.
content.implication_supplier: Provides clear targets for suppliers to meet, reducing uncertainty.
content.text: Having clear acceptance criteria in the contract will benefit both parties.

content.verbatim_text: The required functionality and performance criteria can be described in a separate document which is attached to the agreement.
content.plain_text: Functionality and performance criteria can be detailed in an attached document.
content.expert_insight: This is a practical tactic for managing complex specifications, keeping the main contract concise while allowing for detailed technical requirements to be managed separately.
content.justification: Allows for detailed technical specifications without cluttering the main contract.
content.implication_company: Provides flexibility in managing technical requirements and updates without amending the core agreement.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers can refer to a dedicated document for detailed technical specifications.
content.text: The required functionality and performance criteria can be described in a separate document which is attached to the agreement.

content.verbatim_text: Such subjective or unilateral criteria can, with the assistance of Zebracorp product line or customer team, be replaced by objective and clearly defined acceptance criteria. In fact, this approach would be preferred over agreeing to language where we merely state that acceptance test will be passed when the deliverables ‘substantially conform’ or “materially comply” with the agreed specifications. Such ambiguous language is often prone to disputes.
content.plain_text: Replace subjective or unilateral acceptance criteria (e.g., 'to reasonable satisfaction') with objective, clearly defined criteria, preferably over ambiguous phrases like 'substantially conform' or 'materially comply,' which often lead to disputes.
content.expert_insight: This is a critical drafting principle. Subjective criteria empower the buyer but are prone to disputes. Ambiguous terms like 'substantially' or 'materially' are legal grey areas. Objective, measurable criteria are always preferred for clarity and enforceability.
content.conditions: N/A
content.justification: Ambiguous language is prone to disputes; objective criteria provide clarity and reduce conflict.
content.implication_company: Ensures Zebracorp's acceptance decisions are based on measurable facts, reducing the risk of supplier disputes.
content.implication_supplier: Provides clear, objective targets for suppliers, enabling them to confidently meet requirements.
content.text: Such subjective or unilateral criteria can, with the assistance of Zebracorp product line or customer team, be replaced by objective and clearly defined acceptance criteria. In fact, this approach would be preferred over agreeing to language where we merely state that acceptance test will be passed when the deliverables ‘substantially conform’ or “materially comply” with the agreed specifications. Such ambiguous language is often prone to disputes.

content.verbatim_text: In some instances we can agree that minor deficiencies/errors found during the acceptance tests that do not prevent the intended use of the results of the works will not prevent acceptance, but will be remedied by the subcontractor as part of its warranty obligations or within a certain mutually agreed timeframe.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp can agree that minor, non-critical deficiencies found during acceptance tests won't prevent acceptance, provided the subcontractor remedies them under warranty or within an agreed timeframe.
content.expert_insight: This offers flexibility, allowing for acceptance and project progression even with minor issues, preventing unnecessary delays. It shifts the resolution of non-critical issues to post-acceptance mechanisms like warranty.
content.conditions: Minor deficiencies/errors found during acceptance tests that do not prevent the intended use of the results of the works.
content.justification: Allows for project progression despite minor issues, with remediation handled post-acceptance.
content.implication_company: Enables Zebracorp to accept and utilize deliverables sooner, with assurance that minor issues will be resolved.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers can achieve acceptance faster for deliverables with minor flaws, provided they commit to remediation.
content.text: In some instances we can agree that minor deficiencies/errors found during the acceptance tests that do not prevent the intended use of the results of the works will not prevent acceptance, but will be remedied by the subcontractor as part of its warranty obligations or within a certain mutually agreed timeframe.

content.verbatim_text: Again, in those subcontracts where the supplier is delivering the deliverables directly to Zebracorp’s customer, it is naturally important that the acceptance is sufficiently aligned with Zebracorp’s customer acceptance.
content.plain_text: For subcontracts where suppliers deliver directly to Zebracorp's customer, ensure acceptance is well-aligned with Zebracorp’s customer acceptance.
content.expert_insight: This reiterates the paramount importance of back-to-back alignment in direct-to-customer delivery scenarios, preventing Zebracorp from being caught in a contractual gap.
content.conditions: Subcontracts where the supplier is delivering deliverables directly to Zebracorp’s customer.
content.justification: To avoid misalignment and potential risks for Zebracorp in direct-to-customer delivery models.
content.implication_company: Protects Zebracorp from accepting from a subcontractor before its own customer accepts, preventing financial exposure.
content.implication_supplier: Supplier's acceptance and payment will be directly tied to Zebracorp's customer acceptance.
content.text: Again, in those subcontracts where the supplier is delivering the deliverables directly to Zebracorp’s customer, it is naturally important that the acceptance is sufficiently aligned with Zebracorp’s customer acceptance.

content.verbatim_text: The completion of acceptance should be subject to the successful completion of acceptance tests that are performed by either Zebracorp or our end customers, or, as applicable, both jointly.
content.plain_text: Acceptance completion must depend on successful acceptance tests conducted by Zebracorp, end customers, or both jointly.
content.expert_insight: This establishes Zebracorp's preferred position on who performs the critical acceptance tests, ensuring that the buyer (Zebracorp or its customer) retains control over the validation process.
content.conditions: N/A
content.justification: Ensures Zebracorp or its customer verifies the deliverables meet requirements.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp maintains control over the final verification of deliverables, protecting its interests.
content.implication_supplier: Supplier's deliverables will be subject to rigorous testing by Zebracorp or its end customer.
content.text: The completion of acceptance should be subject to the successful completion of acceptance tests that are performed by either Zebracorp or our end customers, or, as applicable, both jointly.

content.verbatim_text: The supplier/subcontractor participation to the acceptance tests will be at the discretion of Zebracorp and our end customer, as applicable.
content.plain_text: Supplier/subcontractor participation in acceptance tests is at the discretion of Zebracorp and/or its end customer.
content.expert_insight: This reinforces Zebracorp's control over the testing process, allowing them to decide the extent of supplier involvement based on project specifics and trust levels.
content.conditions: N/A
content.justification: Maintains Zebracorp's control over the acceptance testing process.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp retains the right to control who participates in acceptance tests.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers cannot demand participation in acceptance tests; it is subject to Zebracorp's discretion.
content.text: The supplier/subcontractor participation to the acceptance tests will be at the discretion of Zebracorp and our end customer, as applicable.

content.verbatim_text: The agreement should provide Zebracorp sufficient time to complete the acceptance tests.
content.plain_text: The contract must grant Zebracorp adequate time for acceptance tests.
content.expert_insight: This is a fundamental requirement to ensure Zebracorp can thoroughly verify deliverables without being rushed into premature acceptance.
content.conditions: N/A
content.justification: To ensure thorough verification of deliverables.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp secures the necessary time to conduct comprehensive testing.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers must agree to acceptance periods that allow Zebracorp sufficient testing time.
content.text: The agreement should provide Zebracorp sufficient time to complete the acceptance tests.

content.verbatim_text: Failure to complete the tests in a timely manner should not automatically lead to deemed acceptance, but the supplier/subcontractor should first be required to notify Zebracorp in writing and request Zebracorp to complete the acceptance within a reasonable time frame.
content.plain_text: Untimely test completion should not automatically trigger deemed acceptance. Instead, the supplier/subcontractor must first formally notify Zebracorp in writing and request completion within a reasonable timeframe.
content.expert_insight: This is a critical protection against inadvertent deemed acceptance, providing Zebracorp with a formal grace period and notification before any automatic acceptance clause can take effect.
content.conditions: N/A
content.justification: To prevent automatic deemed acceptance and provide Zebracorp with a final opportunity to complete tests.
content.implication_company: Protects Zebracorp from being bound by deemed acceptance due to internal delays, ensuring a formal warning and opportunity to act.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers must follow a formal notification process to trigger deemed acceptance, rather than it occurring automatically.
content.text: Failure to complete the tests in a timely manner should not automatically lead to deemed acceptance, but the supplier/subcontractor should first be required to notify Zebracorp in writing and request Zebracorp to complete the acceptance within a reasonable time frame.

content.verbatim_text: Acceptance should be either final, partial or conditional as indicated by Zebracorp.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp should determine whether acceptance is final, partial, or conditional.
content.expert_insight: This asserts Zebracorp's right to define the nature of acceptance, providing flexibility to manage different project stages and conditions.
content.conditions: N/A
content.justification: Allows Zebracorp to tailor acceptance to specific project needs and conditions.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp retains control over the type of acceptance granted.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers must adhere to the type of acceptance (final, partial, or conditional) specified by Zebracorp.
content.text: Acceptance should be either final, partial or conditional as indicated by Zebracorp.

content.verbatim_text: The [Supplier] shall notify Zebracorp in writing when the [Supplier] considers that the [Works] or the relevant milestone has been completed in accordance with this [Agreement], and request [Zebracorp] to initiate the acceptance tests.
content.plain_text: The supplier must provide written notification to Zebracorp upon perceived completion of works or milestones, requesting the initiation of acceptance tests.
content.expert_insight: This is a standard contractual obligation for suppliers, formalizing the handover process and initiating Zebracorp's acceptance timeline.
content.conditions: N/A
content.justification: Establishes a clear trigger for Zebracorp's acceptance process.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp's acceptance process formally begins upon receipt of supplier's written notice.
content.implication_supplier: Supplier has a formal obligation to notify Zebracorp to initiate acceptance tests.
content.text: The [Supplier] shall notify Zebracorp in writing when the [Supplier] considers that the [Works] or the relevant milestone has been completed in accordance with this [Agreement], and request [Zebracorp] to initiate the acceptance tests.

content.verbatim_text: Within thirty (30) days of receipt of such written notice [Zebracorp] shall, if satisfied that the [Works] or the relevant milestone has been duly completed and the agreed acceptance criteria is met, issue a certificate of acceptance for the milestone in question.
content.plain_text: Within 30 days of receiving the supplier's written notice, Zebracorp must issue an acceptance certificate for the milestone if the works are completed and acceptance criteria are met.
content.expert_insight: This sets a clear, time-bound obligation for Zebracorp to respond to a supplier's readiness notification, ensuring a timely acceptance process.
content.conditions: Zebracorp receives written notice from supplier, and is satisfied that works/milestone are completed and acceptance criteria are met.
content.justification: Provides a clear timeframe for Zebracorp's response and formalizes acceptance.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp is obligated to perform acceptance checks and issue a certificate within 30 days if conditions are met.
content.implication_supplier: Supplier can expect a formal acceptance certificate within 30 days if their deliverables meet criteria.
content.text: Within thirty (30) days of receipt of such written notice [Zebracorp] shall, if satisfied that the [Works] or the relevant milestone has been duly completed and the agreed acceptance criteria is met, issue a certificate of acceptance for the milestone in question.

content.verbatim_text: Such acceptance can be partial or conditional as indicated in [Zebracorp’] acceptance certificate.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp's acceptance certificate can specify if acceptance is partial or conditional.
content.expert_insight: This reinforces Zebracorp's flexibility in granting different types of acceptance, as previously discussed.
content.conditions: N/A
content.justification: Allows for flexible acceptance based on project status or remaining conditions.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can issue nuanced acceptance certificates reflecting the exact status of deliverables.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers must understand that acceptance may not always be final and unconditional.
content.text: Such acceptance can be partial or conditional as indicated in [Zebracorp’] acceptance certificate.

content.verbatim_text: In the event that [Zebracorp] is not satisfied that the [Works] and/or the relevant milestone has been completed or if the agreed acceptance criteria or other agreed requirements are not met, [Zebracorp] shall notify [Supplier] thereof within the aforementioned time limit and, at the request of the [Supplier], provide the reasons for refusing the acceptance.
content.plain_text: If Zebracorp is not satisfied that works/milestones are completed or acceptance criteria/requirements are unmet, Zebracorp must notify the supplier within the specified timeframe and, if requested, provide reasons for refusal.
content.expert_insight: This is a critical obligation for Zebracorp, ensuring transparency and providing the supplier with clear feedback if acceptance is denied. This helps prevent disputes and facilitates remediation.
content.conditions: Zebracorp is not satisfied that works/milestone are completed or acceptance criteria/requirements are not met.
content.justification: Provides clear communication to the supplier regarding non-acceptance and reasons for refusal, facilitating remediation.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp has a formal obligation to communicate non-acceptance and provide justification within a set timeframe.
content.implication_supplier: Supplier receives timely and justified feedback if deliverables are not accepted, enabling them to address issues.
content.text: In the event that [Zebracorp] is not satisfied that the [Works] and/or the relevant milestone has been completed or if the agreed acceptance criteria or other agreed requirements are not met, [Zebracorp] shall notify [Supplier] thereof within the aforementioned time limit and, at the request of the [Supplier], provide the reasons for refusing the acceptance.

content.verbatim_text: The [Supplier] shall promptly remedy any failures or deficiencies in meeting the acceptance criteria set out below and/or such other agreed requirements, and also rectify and remedy any and all defects and deficiencies identified by [Zebracorp] and/or [Zebracorp’s] customer during the acceptance tests and inform [Zebracorp] in writing upon completing such remedial action.
content.plain_text: The supplier must promptly remedy any failures, deficiencies, or defects identified by Zebracorp or its customer during acceptance tests, and notify Zebracorp in writing once remedial actions are complete.
content.expert_insight: This establishes a clear and strong obligation for the supplier to address non-compliance and defects, and to formally communicate when remediation is complete, setting the stage for re-testing or re-evaluation.
content.conditions: Failures, deficiencies, or defects identified during acceptance tests.
content.justification: Ensures non-compliant deliverables are corrected and Zebracorp is formally informed of remediation.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can rely on the supplier to promptly correct issues and provide written confirmation.
content.implication_supplier: Supplier has a clear obligation to fix issues and formally report completion, which is crucial for subsequent acceptance.
content.text: The [Supplier] shall promptly remedy any failures or deficiencies in meeting the acceptance criteria set out below and/or such other agreed requirements, and also rectify and remedy any and all defects and deficiencies identified by [Zebracorp] and/or [Zebracorp’s] customer during the acceptance tests and inform [Zebracorp] in writing upon completing such remedial action.

content.verbatim_text: [Zebracorp] will issue the certificate of acceptance only after having satisfied itself that such deficiencies and defects have been duly remedied and rectified, and the [Works] or the relevant part thereof has been completed and all of the requirements for issuing the certificate of acceptance in this [Agreement] have been met.”
content.plain_text: Zebracorp will only issue an acceptance certificate after verifying that all identified deficiencies and defects have been remedied, the works are completed, and all contractual requirements for acceptance are met.
content.expert_insight: This is a critical protective clause for Zebracorp, ensuring that acceptance is contingent upon full and verified remediation of all issues and complete fulfillment of all contractual obligations.
content.conditions: Deficiencies and defects have been duly remedied and rectified, works are completed, and all requirements for issuing the certificate of acceptance are met.
content.justification: Ensures Zebracorp only accepts fully compliant and corrected deliverables.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp retains the right to withhold acceptance until all conditions are unequivocally met, protecting its interests.
content.implication_supplier: Supplier must ensure all issues are fully resolved and requirements met before Zebracorp will issue an acceptance certificate.
content.text: [Zebracorp] will issue the certificate of acceptance only after having satisfied itself that such deficiencies and defects have been duly remedied and rectified, and the [Works] or the relevant part thereof has been completed and all of the requirements for issuing the certificate of acceptance in this [Agreement] have been met.”

content.verbatim_text: The acceptance criteria and acceptance procedures should always be aligned with the end customer acceptance provisions in any such subcontracts that are specifically made for a particular end customer project.
content.plain_text: For subcontracts tied to specific end customer projects, the acceptance criteria and procedures must always align with the end customer's acceptance provisions.
content.expert_insight: This is a final, emphatic reiteration of the 'back-to-back' alignment principle, underscoring its critical importance for any project-specific subcontracting.
content.conditions: Subcontracts specifically made for a particular end customer project.
content.justification: To ensure seamless project execution, prevent contractual gaps, and mitigate financial and operational risks for Zebracorp.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must ensure its contractual obligations to subcontractors match its rights and obligations with its end customer.
content.implication_supplier: Supplier's acceptance and payment terms will be directly influenced by Zebracorp's customer contract terms.
content.text: The acceptance criteria and acceptance procedures should always be aligned with the end customer acceptance provisions in any such subcontracts that are specifically made for a particular end customer project.
